title: 107_hr2210
content: The Act may be cited as the "America's Youth Commission Act of 2001". Congress acknowledges that American youth, up to 18 years of age, are the freest, most educated, and most affluent generation in the nation's history. Despite favorable conditions, destructive behaviors among some youth are harming the nation and hindering their full potential to contribute to freedom's cause. Some American youth are engaging in destructive behaviors such as youth violence, school pranks, alcohol and drug use, and gun violence, hindering their potential to contribute to society. American youth in the United States are exposed to high levels of violence and degrading material in the media, leading to concerns about the erosion of human dignity. This "culture of death" is seen as influencing the behavior and consciousness of American youth. The community in the United States has undergone significant changes in the past 30 years due to economic growth and mobility, affecting families' aspirations and livelihoods. Factors such as static purchasing power, mergers, production dislocation, higher family mobility, suburbanization, and rising levels of foster children have contributed to a more fluid social structure. This has led to less continuity for youth in nurturing relationships with family and community, with developmental attachments by adults towards youth becoming more fragile in today's society. The "National Commission on the Impact of United States Culture on America's Youth" is established by this Act. The Commission's duty is outlined in Section 4. The Commission will investigate and make recommendations on the condition of contemporary youth in America compared to prior generations, focusing on family, schools, work, and community involvement. It will also analyze the origins and trends of antisocial and violent behavior among American youth, including the influence of organizations and cultural elements. Additionally, the Commission will identify successful initiatives that promote positive development and curb antisocial behavior among youth. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for averting and reducing violence among American youth, as well as suggestions for building positive developmental experiences for youth by parents, families, and various organizations. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various leaders and the President. Members must not be current Members of Congress and should have relevant qualifications. Each member serves for the life of the Commission without pay. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various leaders and the President, who serve without pay. Members receive travel expenses and a quorum is seven members. The Chairperson is designated by the President at the time of appointment. The Commission, consisting of 11 members appointed by various leaders and the President, has powers outlined in SEC. 6. The Commission, as outlined in SEC. 6, has the authority to hold public hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and administrative support services can be requested. The Commission, as outlined in SEC. 6, has the authority to hold public hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties. Upon request, the Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission also has the authority to contract with and compensate Government or private agencies for supplies or services. The Commission will submit an interim report to the President and Congress within 180 days of organization, and a final report within one year. The final report will include findings, conclusions, and legislative recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002 to carry out the Act.
